H0.text: The changing of the seasons is caused by Earth’s orbit around the Sun.

H1.text: Daily tidal cycles are caused by Earth orbiting the Sun.

H2.text: Day to become night is caused by Earth orbiting the Sun.

H3.text: The phases of the Moon are caused by Earth orbiting the Sun.

A4.text: The seasons are not the result of the variation in Earth's distance to the Sun because of its elliptical orbit.

A5.text: The seasons result from the Earth's axis of rotation being tilted with respect to its orbital plane by an angle of approximately 23.4 degrees.

A6.text: Earth's axis remains tilted in the same direction with reference to the background stars throughout a year – this is the cause of Earth's seasons.

A7.text: The Moon has a stabilizing effect on Earth's obliquity.

A8.text: The changing Earth-Sun distance results in an increase of about 7% in total solar energy reaching the Earth at perihelion relative to aphelion.

A9.text: The seasons of the solstices and equinoxes in the southern hemisphere are the reverse of those in the northern hemisphere.

A10.text: The resulting theory, however, was incorrect as he attributed the tides to the sloshing of water caused by the Earth's movement around the Sun.

A11.text: Isaac Newton (1642–1727) was the first person to explain tides as the product of the gravitational attraction of astronomical masses.

A12.text: The phases of the Moon are caused by the Moon's shadow on itself and the angle of the Sun relative to the Moon.

A13.text: The visible side of the Moon is sunlit to varying extents, depending on the position of the Moon in its orbit.
